p.seg: pêyak , nipâkwêsimôwin . One is the Sun-Dance.
êh-nitotamâht manitôw , kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw kitaw-ohpikit ôtah askîhk . The Sun-Dance consists of this, that God is entreated that every human being may grow up and thrive here on this earth.

êwako nipâkwêsimôwin , nîso-kîsikâw pikoh aniki kâ-nîmihitocik nipiy êkâ ê-minihkwêcik , êkwa mîciwin êkâ êh-mîcicik nîso-kîsikâw . The Sun-Dance consists of this, that for two days and no longer the dancers drink no water and for two days eat no food.
mayaw kâ-pôyihk , sêmâk kahkiyaw kîwâniwiw , ê-ntaw-âtoskêhk . As soon as it is over, at once all go home and return to work.
namoya wîhkâc êh-kisiwâsihk , êwako mîkiwâhp k-âpacihtâcik nêhiyawak . It is never in anger that the Cree use this lodge.

êyako kahkiyaw . That is all. LB: The insistence upon prompt return to work and upon absence of black magic (“it is never in anger”) are, of course, pleas for the dances, some of which have been forbidden by the government. The informant spoke much more freely when notes were not being taken; when dictating he broke off at frequent intervals with, “That is all.” Then, when reminded of some feature he had left out, he would go on for a while. This accounts for the form of our text.
pîsim piyêsiw mostos ohtin , êwakonik nêwo k-ôh-nipâkwêsimohk , êh-miyâcik ayîsiyiniwah êwakonik . Sun, Thunderbird, Buffalo, Wind, for these four the Sun-Dance is danced, since they gave it to man.

manitôw otawâsimisah ê-kîh-wiyâhât kita-nitotamâht pimâtisiwin , êwakonik âcimostawêwak ôhtâwiyiwâwa manitôwah . Since God appointed these his children, that he might be entreated for life, it is they who convey the message to God their Father.
êkosi êwakô ohci kâ-nipâkwêsimohk ; namoya êh-mâyâtahk . This, then, is the purpose of the Sun-Dance; not evil.
mistahi mihcêtwâw ohcih pimâtisiwak nêhiyawak . In many instances Cree owe their lives to it.
ayis namoya êyakonih piko êh-ntotamôwâcik kit-ôh-pimâtisicik ; But, in fact, it is not only for themselves that they ask for the power to live;
kahkiyaw kitaw-ohpikit ayîsiyiniw ôtah ôm âskiy êy-isi-nitotahkik kâ-nipâkwêsimôwinihkêcik . that every human being on this earth may thrive is the prayer of them who celebrate the Sun-Dance.
êh-âhkosit awiyak , asotam ta-wîcihiwêt , ta-nîmihitot , manitôwah êh-ntotamôwât . When one is ill, he makes a vow that he will take part in the dance and the prayer to God.
tâpwê âskaw pimâtisiwak êkotah ohci nêhiyawak . Truly, often have Cree owed their lives to this.
pîhtwâhêwak êwakonih ôhi kahkiyaw , ôhi pîsimwah mîna piyêsiwah mîna mostoswa mîna ohtinah . They cause each of them to smoke, the Sun and the Thunderbird and the Buffalo and the Wind.
êwakonih mînah wâpahtêhêwak cistêmâwa . They show them the tobacco.

awa kâ-wîh-nipâkwêsimôwinihkêt ,
kitâpaht ôma ! He who is about to give the Sun-Dance, “Look upon this thing!

seg.q: kitâpam awah , nôhtâ kisê-manitôw , kitawâsimis êh-wîh-kanawêyihtamawak kita-pîhtwât !
seg.gloss: Look upon this tobacco, God, my Father, which I shall keep for Thy child to smoke.

seg.q: miy sôhkisiwin awa kitawâsimis kâ-kanawêyihtamawak cistêmâwa .
seg.gloss: Give power to Thy child for whom I keep the tobacco.
Moderate him, so that mortal men be not frightened by aught.

seg.q: itah mânokêyâni , kitawâsimisak kâ-wîh-mânokawakik , kita-kitâpahtahkik wîkiwâw taw-okimâwahk êkâ awiyak kitah-âhkosit ;
seg.gloss: There where I set up the lodge which I am about to erect for Thy children to look upon, let no one be ill;
seg.note: LB on {taw-okimâwahk}: Doubtless error of record.

seg.q: kahkiyaw kiyâm kita-miywayihtamwak ôki kitawâsimisak , tahtoh kê-pê-ntawâpahkêcik ôma pîsim piyêsiw wîkih kâ-wîh-osîhtâyân , ohtin mîna .
seg.gloss: let all Thy children rejoice in it, as many as shall come to look upon this lodge of Sun and Thunderbird which I shall build, and of the Wind.

seg.q: êyakonik kita-kisêwâtisiwak koyahâkanak , kâ-sôhkahk kipimâcihiwêwin , êwakoh kita-miyihcik kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak .
seg.gloss: May these Thy appointed creatures be propitious, so that Thy firm gift of life may be given to all men.
When here I stand let them not by aught be frightened.

seg.q: wâh-pimohtêcih kitawâsimis , pêyahtik kita-pimohtêw awa piyêsiw , nipiy kita-sâpopatât ohcih omâ askiy , êkâ ta-pîkopayik .
seg.gloss: When Thy child is about to walk abroad, let this Thunderbird go gently, drenching this earth with rain, that it may not break apart.
Be kind to me; hear me with pity!
Thus do I now speak, that all may live in health.”

p.seg: êyako kahkiyaw . That is all of this.

kîspin piyêsiw êh-miyât êwako mîkiwâhp , kâ-mânokêt ayîsiyiniw , mistahi âpacihiwêw . If the Thunderbird gives a man this lodge, and he has set it up, he does much good to people. LB: Informant had explained that not anyone, but only he who had been so commanded in a vision by a Thunderer, could give a Sun-Dance.
kahkiyaw awiya âpacihêw , êkâ ta-nôhtêyâpâkwêyit , ta-miyoskâkoyit nipiy . He does good to each and every one, that they need not thirst and that water may benefit them.
êyakô ohci ayîsiyiniwak , pêyak kâ-nipâkwêsimôwinihkêt . This is why; for the sake of mankind is why one gives a Sundance.
kahkiyaw êkosi . That, then, is all.
êkwa kotak êyakwa . Now another.
pêyakwan pîhtwâwin , pêyak tipiskâw pikoh ê-nikamohk , sîsîkwanak êh-âpacihihcik . Of similar nature is the Smoking-Lodge, in which the singing lasts only one night and rattles are used.
pêyak wâkayôs êwako nîkân ê-wîhtamâkêt , nêhiyawah ê-wîhtamawât . It was a certain bear who first told of this, revealing it to the Cree.
êkotah ohci : pîsim piyêsiw mostos . It is for these: Sun, Thunderbird, Buffalo.
pikw îtôwahk asiniy apiw pîhcâyihk . Somewhere within the lodge lies a stone.
êyakonik êh-miyihcik cistêmâwa , kita-pîhtwâcik , êh-ntotamâhcik pimâtisiwin . It is they who are given tobacco that they may smoke and are entreated for life.
tâpitâwih pîhcâyihk pîhtwâwikamikohk mîcisonâniwiw , minihkwâniwiw nipiy . But also, within the Smoking-Lodge there is eating, and water is drunk.
nôtokêsiwak mânokêwak pîhtwâwikamik , namoya nâpêwak . Old women erect the Smoking-Lodge, not men.
namoya nîmihitôwak . They do not dance.
tahtoh êh-nikamocik , kiyîsi-nikamotwâwi , ntotamawêwak kitaw-ohci-pimâtisicik . Every time they sing, when they have sung their song, they ask them for the gift of life.
tahto kâ-nikamocik , kahkiyaw êwakonik êh-ntotamâcik . As many as sing, all ask them for it.
âskaw pîhcâyihk mâtôw ayîsiyiniw kâ-pîhtwâwinihkêt . From time to time within the lodge he weeps who is giving the Smoking-Ceremony.

ôki awâsisak kit-ôhpikiwak miyinân , kit-ôh-ohpikinâwasoyâhk ! itwêwak kâ-pîhtwâcik . “Grant us that these children may grow up, grant us the gift of bringing our children to maturity!” say those who smoke.
tahto mîna kâ-nikamocik , kahkiyaw miyâwak cistêmâwa , tahto kâ-nikamocik . As many, also, as sing, all are given tobacco, as many as sing.
âskaw iskwêwak mâtôwak . From time to time the women weep.

seg.gloss: “Lend a pitying ear to our prayer!

seg.q: kitimâkêyim ôki nâpêwak , ê-kitimâkisicik , ê-ntotamâkoyêkok pimâtisiwin .
seg.gloss: Pity these men, who are pitiable, who implore you for life.

seg.q: ôki mîna iskwêwak t-ôhpikihêwak otawâsimisiwâwa kitimâkêyiminân , kisê-manitôw !
seg.gloss: And that these women, also, may bring their children to maturity, take pity on us, Lord God!

seg.q: ôki kitawâsimisak kâ-wîci-pîhtwâmihcik miy kit-ôh-kitimâkêyihtahkik kêkway , t-ôhpikîmakaniyik wiyawâw .
seg.gloss: To those children who are given part in the smoking, grant, that they may feel pity for all things, and that their bodies may grow and thrive.
Let not Thy child, the Thunderbird try to frighten us.

seg.q: mîna ohtin êkâ wiya itah êh-ayât ayîsiyiniw kakwê-sêkihtâ miywâsin kohpikihcikêwin .
seg.gloss: Do not with Wind, there where is mortal man, seek to frighten that good thing Thou hast caused to grow up.
Even thus grant us Thy pity!”

p.seg: êkosi kahkiyaw . That is all.

êh-pôni-mâtocik ôki iskwêwak , pêyak ê-mâtot ,
hay ! itâw ,
kitatamihin ê-ntotamâkêstamawiyan pimâtisiwin ! When the women cease to weep, when one has wept, “Thanks!” they say to her; “I thank you for praying for me for life!”

êh-itêyimâcik , êh-mâtoyit , pêskis êh-pîkiskwêyit ,
mâskôc ta-kitimâkihtawâw , êh-itêyihtahkik ôk âyîsiyiniwak ,
hay ! k-ôh-itwêcik . Because those people think thus concerning her, when she weeps and at the same time speaks her prayer, because they think “Doubtless she will be heard with pity,” that is why they say, “Thanks!”

êkosi êyako pêyak tipiskâw êh-pôyohk , mayaw êh-kîsikâk , sêmâk kahkiyaw kîwêwak ayîsiyiniwak . Then, when after that one night the ceremony is closed, as soon as day comes, at once all the people go home.
mistahi kîwêhtatâwak mîciwin . They take home much food.

mistah kîsitêpôw êwako aniki êh-pîhtwât awiyak , pêyak piko omîciwin kâ-miyât , kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah ta-mîciyit . When anyone of these people thus smokes, he cooks much, for he alone gives them food, that all the people may eat.
mayaw êh-pôyohk , kîwâniwiw nanânis . As soon as the ceremony is over, all go to their various homes.
êako kahkiyaw . That is all of this.
kotak mina nîmihitôwin : kikastotinêwak . Another dance still: they dance the Masked-Dance.

êkwah mistikohk tâpisiniyiwa mostoswak waskasîwâhk ohci êh-apisîsisicik . To a pole are fastened the smallest of the hoofs of buffalo. LB: Or, “small things (animate: rattles?) made of buffalo-hoofs.”
êyakonik pêyak kîsikâw êh-kîsikâyik piko êh-nîmihitocik . These dancers dance one day, only during daylight.
kahkiyaw mâka kikastotinêwak . All wear a headgear.
payipisikâtêyiwa otastotiniwâwa itah êh-ohci-kanawâpahkêcik . holes are cut in their headgear, through which they may see.
êwako mîna pêyakwan , wîhtikôhkânisimôwin . This, too, is of the same nature, the Windigo-Dance.
êyakô pêyakwan : tahki mîcisôwak ; pisisik nâpêwak , namoya iskwêwak . This is alike in both: they always eat; there are only men, not women.

pêyakwan mîn êyakô pâh-pêyak piko kâ-miyihcik ayîsiyiniwak , êyako nîmihitôwin , namoya waniyaw , pêyak piko nâpêw . This, too, is a common feature, that only certain individuals are given the gift of holding this dance; not anybody, but only this or that man.
âskaw nisto-mitanaw nîsitanaw nê-mitanaw ihtasiwak ôki kâ-wîhtikôh-kânisimocik . Sometimes the Windigo-Dancers were as many as thirty, twenty, or forty in number.
êyakonik êh-asotahkik kitaw-ohci-pimâtisicik , wâhyaw êh-ayâyit owâhkomâkaniwâwa . They promised to hold it that they might derive life from it, when their kinsfolk were far away.

seg.gloss: “God, let me see my kinsfolk, Thy children.
Then I shall give them a dance.
If I look upon him who laments in sickness, let him live.
By this lodge I shall take my seat.

p.seg: nika-nîmihâwak ayîsiyiniwak , itwêw . I shall make the people dance,” he said.
tâpwê pimâtisiyiwa . Then truly the others would live.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk êyako . That is the end of this.
kayâs tâpiskôc simâkanisak nêhiyawak . Of old, like soldiers were the Cree.
namoya kîmôc kîh-tôtamwak . They did not act without general consent.

mayaw onîmihitôwak , êyakonik pisisik nâpêwak kayâs , kîspin onîmihitôwak ,
namoya ka-mâcînâwâw ; namoya ka-mâcîw awiyak , kîspin êkosi êh-itwêcik , awiyak miyâcîci , mênahoci , ôki onîmihitôwak , âtah ,
kîmôc nitôtên , êtêyihtahkih awa kâ-mâcît , têpiskâyiki , têkosihkih , wiyâpahkih pêhtamwak onîmihitôwak . As soon as these dancers, - they were only men, of old, - as soon as these dancers said, “You are not to hunt; no one is to hunt,” then, if anyone hunted and killed game, then these dancers, even though that hunter would think, “I am doing it in secret,” when at night he has arrived, in the morning those dancers would hear it.
kîkisêpâ wayawîwak ; sâkowêwak ; nikamôwak . Early in the morning they would go forth; they would whoop; they sang.
êkosi pîkonêwak . Then they tore up his belongings.
awa kâ-kîh-mâcît wîkih yâyikisamwân , misiwê êh-pîkosamoht . The tent of the one who had hunted would be cut into strips, and all his property cut up.
opâskisikan otinamwân . His gun would be taken from him.

seg.gloss: “You see, friends, my children are hungry; that is why I have transgressed against you.
Do you keep this tobacco to smoke.

p.seg: iyikohk kîh-nêwo-tipiskâk , êkospi kika-miyitinâwâw isi-miywêyihtamêk , itwêw awa nâpêw . In four nights I shall give you that which will please you,” said that man.
kâh-nêwo-tipiskâki pakamahwêw atimwah , êh-nipahât otêma . When the fourth night had come, he clubbed his dog to death; he killed his dog.
pakâsimêw , onîmihitôwak ê-ntaw-asamihcik . He set it to boil, and the dancers were sent for, that they might partake of it.

kâ-kîs-asamihtwâwi ôk ônîmihitôwak , êkwah ,
hâw , awa kâ-kî-pîkoswâyahk , nikwêmêsitik , namoya kikisiwâhânaw . When the dancers had been given it to eat, then, “Now, he whose belongings we have cut to pieces, friends, we have not angered him.

seg.q: miyihk apasoyah , mîkiwâhp ; mîn ayôwinisah miyihk .
seg.gloss: Give him tent-poles and a tipi; give him also clothes.”

p.seg: hâ , êkwah kahkiyaw onîmihitôwak miyêwak t-âpacihtâyit , pâskisikan môsasiniyah mîkiwâhp apasoyah . Then all the dancers would give him things to use, a gun, bullets, a tipi, lodge-poles.
êkos îsi miyâw , kîspin êkâya kisiwâsit . With such things he was presented, if he did not get angry.
mâk âwa kâ-kisiwâhiht , wîkih êh-pîkosamoht , nama kêkway miyâw . But one who was made angry by the destruction of his dwelling, was not given anything.
tâpwê piko kitimâkisiw , kahkiyaw êh-pîkonamoht otayânah otayôwinisah opâskisikan . He was indeed reduced to misery, what with the tearing up of all his implements, his clothes, and his gun.
êyako kahkiyaw . That is all.
êkwah pêyak ; ocihkomisîsak isiyîhkâsôwak onîmihitôwak . And another; Little Lousy Fellows the dancers were called.
kâkikê wîkiwâw cimatêyiw pîhtêyis , mîkiwâhp , êyakonik onîmihitôwak . Their lodge stood permanently in the center of the camp, the lodge of these dancers.
ôki mîna kotakak sîsîkwanisak isiyîhkâsôwak onîmihitôwak . And another society of dancers was called the Little Rattles.
êh-kîsikâyik nîmihitôwak . They danced by daylight.
pisisik nâpêwak . They were all men.
iskwêwak naskwahamâkêwak , êh-nikamocik . The women made the chorus as they sang.
êkwah kotakak , mistah-âtimwak . And another society, the Big Dogs.
pisisik nâpêwak . They were men only.
pêyakwan êkos îsi nîmihitôwak , iskwêwa êh-nikamoyit ; namoya êh-nîmihitoyit . They danced in the same way, the women singing, but not dancing.
nâpêwak pisisik . They were all men.
kotakak mina onîmihitôwak pihêwak isiyîhkâsôwak . Another society of dancers was called the Partridges.
pêyakwan êkos êh-tôtahkik . They did like the preceding.
kîspin awiyak mostoswa êh-nipahât , pîkonâw . If anyone killed a buffalo, his possessions were torn up.

ôki kahkiyaw kâ-wîhakik onîmihitôwak pîhtêyas êh-wîkicik , êh-wîhkwêstêkih mîkiwâhpah . All these dancers whom I have named, had their lodge in the center, where the other tipis stood in a circle round about.
êyakô kahkiyaw pêyakwan êyako wêyasowêwin , nam âwiya kita-mâcît , asêyas piko kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw ta-mâcît ; They all had the same rule, that no one was to hunt, except when all hunted in a band;
êyako êy-oyasowâtahkik onîmihitowak , that was the law of the dancers.

kîksêpâ pêyak wîhtam , êh-papâ-têpwêt :
êkos îtwêwak onîmihitôwak , êh-itwêt aw âyîsiyiniw , êh-wîhtamôwât kahkiyaw âwiya . Early in the morning one would announce it, going about and crying, “So and so say the dancers,” announcing it to every one.
êyako êkoyikohk iskoh . êkosi . That is all.

anohc pîtos nîmihitôwin , êh-mîcisohk , kahkiyaw , awâsisak , iskwêwak , kahkiyaw êh-itohtatahk mîciwin , ayâpisîs pêyak askihkohk piko . Today the dancing is different; there is eating. Everyone, children and women, bring food, each one a small amount, in a kettle.
pîyis mistahi pîhcâyihk astêw mîciwin . In the end there is a good amount of food in the tent.

namoya pêyak tipiskâw ; nohtaw êh-âpihtâ-tipiskâk poyonâniwa . Not one night; they stop before midnight. LB: This last is no doubt the “pow-wow”, Cree {pîcicîwak}, literally, “they attract”. An old time dance described by Coming-Day but not mentioned in our text, was the Pole-Dance, {awatâhtikwêwak}, literally, “they carry sticks”. Sticks were set up upright in the ground, four ropes attached to each, and each rope held by a dancer. The dancers were on horseback, two young men and two young women riding around each stick. Another feature not in this text is the form of the lodge: the Smoking-Lodge is conical, shaped like an ordinary tipi; the Sun-Dance lodge is straight upright (in a circle) and has a conical top.
